Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Vulnerability-Agnostic Secure Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be safer and more secure IoT platforms that will contribute to the growth of the IoT market. Current security technologies in the IoT arena are either weak or expensive (usually both). The weakness in conventional approaches lies in their impractical goal of finding and fixing all security vulnerabilities. Modern systems have complexity that vastly outstrips the capabilities of any human or verification tool to find all the security vulnerabilities. The only way to somewhat mitigate this weakness is to throw significant resources at the problem, which is very expensive and still yields an imperfect result. The proposed technology developed in this SBIR Phase I project will provide practical and strong security. It gains these important properties by assuming that all systems are riddled with vulnerabilities, so it builds in security by making IoT computing devices that are unsolvable puzzles to attackers. In addition, it doesn't rely on IoT developers to deploy hand-crafted defenses; instead, developers simply build their applications on the proposed platform, and they receive all of its security benefits.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a new direction in IoT security. Unlike the world of IoT security today, where developers and tools are attempting to find and fix every last security vulnerability (and always failing), the technology being developed is a hardware-based secure IoT technology that is impractically difficult to penetrate. It achieves this by engaging ensembles of moving target defenses (EMTDs) on the runtime information that attackers need to build their attacks. To overcome EMTDs, attackers must extensively probe the system to acquire the run-time information obscured by moving target defenses. To stop these probes, the technology utilizes a technology called churn to re-key moving target defenses while the system is in operation. Once the churn mechanism is engaged, attackers will have to start their attack over again from scratch. With churn cycles of 50ms (or less), the proposed secure IoT platform becomes impractically difficult to breach, across a broad array of attack classes. The work proposed in this SBIR Phase I project will advance the technology from simulation to a real hardware implementation, which will allow the technology to be deployed into the IoT marketplace.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted in our NSF SBIR Phase I grant set out to implement the Morpheus secure CPU architecture and perform security evaluation of architecture, targeted to Internet-of-Things (IoT) applications. The Morpheus secure CPU architecture works to broadly stop security attacks. Specifically, Morpheus provides significant protections against both common and advanced attacks. It delivers broad defenses against attacks through the deployment of high-entropy ciphers, which do the work of turning a computer into an unsolvable puzzle designed to frustrate would-be attackers.

To demonstrate the Morpheus secure CPU architecture and its ability to stop real-world security attacks, we undertook an effort to implement the design. This effort was completed successfully, and it allowed a deeper inspection of the design’s security features. To gauge the security benefits of Morpheus, we performed a penetration study of its ability to stop a wide range of security attacks, ranging from common long-standing attacks (e.g., buffer overflow) to hard-to-stop advanced attacks (e.g., return-oriented programming). We then attempted to build Morpheus-specific attacks to assess the durability of Morpheus security when new attacks were crafted with its capabilities in mind. Through these tests, the Morpheus secure architecture was shown to stop all the tested attacks. Additionally, all attacks triggered our attack detector, thus the system itself was aware that it was being attacked while the attack was ongoing.

Finally, as a company we undertook the task of finding our first market and then locating promising customers within that market. Working with NSF mentors we performed extensive customer discovery, targeted at the US defense contractor market. After performing extensive customer discovery (with 47 potential customers), engaging in the NSF Beat-the-Odds Bootcamp, and pitching the Morpheus Secure IoT CPU to approximately 15 VCs, we began to realize that our chosen path to build a silicon-based secure IoT processor for the US defense contractor market was a problematic one. Simply put, the lead times for US defense contractor products were greater than 5 years, and surprisingly there was not enough emphasis placed on security when building defense products. Moreover, building a custom silicon processor would require significant capital investment. Given the challenges of our first market, we decided to pivot the company’s product direction toward developing next-level data security for the cloud computing market. This is an ongoing effort, which builds on the research of our Phase I work, but fine tunes our direction in preparation for our Phase II proposal and beyond.
